title: Can you act as an animal in front of a wild animal to protect yourself? Would they be scared? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends on which animal you act like, right? If you are being threatened by a bear, acting like a salmon would be a very bad choice. As far as we know, other species don’t classify other species the same way we do. They are a lot more concerned with behaviour. If you make a lot of noise and make yourself look bigger when threatened by a predator, they may decide to leave you alone, not because they mistake you for a non-human, but because you look like you’ll be more trouble than you’re worth. On the other hand, if you turn and run away, you’re acting like prey, and they’re more likley to chase. Animal agression isn’t always predation, however. When a rattlesnake coils and rattles, she’s saying, “leave me alone or you’ll regret it”. Back away slowly, to the point where she feels safe to turn her attention from you, and she’ll leave. The most serious encounter I’ve ever had with a non-human was a male elk during rutting season. There was nothing I could do to convince him that I was not interested in his women. He chased me several times around my car, before I was able to jump inside and slam the door. He snorted like he’d proved which of us were more manly (and he was certainly correct) and swaggered off with his harem. (For the record, I did nothing to provoke this. He brought his harem into my campsight uninvited, and I didn’t even check them out.) What is needed in encounters with other species is an understanding of why they are showing threatening behaviour, and knowing what is the most appropriate behaviour to respond to the threat.

The scariest possible thing you can be to a wild animal—is yourself. A human. We are the most terrifying being they could encounter. Most wild animals are very aware of this and try to avoid humans at all costs. So act like a human. Stand tall, talk calmly to them, and let them see your front-facing (predator’s) eyes (just don’t stare them in the eye; that is usually seen as aggressive and wanting to fight). I’m not sure what you mean by acting like an animal—maybe growling or getting down on all fours? None of the options I can think of are a good idea, regardless, and would be more likely to entice them to attack.

You can, but knowing what you're facing will tell you whether or not it would work. Some animals would be intimidated, hesitate, run away. Don't try that on a polar bear, or gorilla, or hippo, just to name a few more well known examples. How you react is determined by what you're facing. A tactic that may work on a black bear may not work on a grizzly bear. All of the tactics for black bears and grizzly are a bad idea for polar bears. A tactic that may scare off a lion may only aggitate a leopard or jaguar for another example. This applies with omnivorous and herbivorous animals as well. What may spook a deer or elk will only piss off a moose
